Blurb
Overview
The purpose of Veterinary Infection Biology is to provide students with detailed knowledge of infectious diseases in livestock and companion animals, as well the contemporary research techniques used at the University of Liverpool (UoL) to acquire such knowledge.

Our intention is for students to acquire
(1) accurate understanding of the prevailing scientific consensus on disease cause and control,
(2) understanding of how new knowledge is being exploited to improve outcomes in the disease setting, and
(3) a good appreciation for the research process, how problems are addressed and data interpreted.

The module will cover nine different infectious diseases including viral, bacterial and parasitological pathogens, building on basic biology of these organisms delivered in years 1 and 2. All of these diseases comprise active research programmes at the University, and teaching will be research-led, drawing on diverse methods (molecular, cellular, epidemiology, clinical). It is delivered through a combination of lectures, research seminars, small-group tutorials and practicals. The module is assessed by an extended piece of writing and a report.

The forms of assessment will encourage students to scrutinize the research process and actively prepare them for postgraduate studies by focusing on
(1) new research skills gained in practical sessions and
(2) scientific interpretation in tutorials.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to deliver an advanced biology of global veterinary infectious disease and to immerse students in the research process at UoL. Our intention is that the module will prepare students for postgraduate study and instil confidence in them to consider careers in research. The module covers nine topics spanning the spectrum of veterinary pathogens. The module fulfils the Liverpool Hallmarks; all topics are active research programmes at UoL, meaning that we can deliver authentic research-led teaching.

There are five objectives:

1. Deliver advanced knowledge from multiple research perspectives (i.e. molecular biology, genetics, epidemiology, ecology, clinical) to a level that approaches a professional standard.

2. Explicitly link basic biology to translational research at UoL, ensuring that all content is outcome-orientated and authentically research-led.

3. Explicitly link basic biology to clinical research and practice at UoL, ensuring that content is secured in its global veterinary context, (including one-health perspectives where appropriate), to produce a holistic understanding of disease cause and control that relates real-world complexities.

4. Describe the contemporary molecular, epidemiological and computational techniques used in veterinary infection biology research at UoL, providing practical experience of select methods to students, and demonstrate how diverse data are interpreted to create knowledge in the research process.

5. Cultivate students’ understanding and spoken communication skills in relation to select topics through regular active learning, and develop their critical analysis skills with regard to scientific consensus and research process through authentic assessment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Infectious disease is a key aspect of animal health and well-being, and so understanding infection is critical for people working with animals or veterinarians. This module explains the detailed biology of important animal infections and how this is being translated into novel disease therapies, drawing on the first-hand experience of veterinary scientists at the University of Liverpool. It is delivered through a combination of lectures, research seminars, small-group tutorials and practicals. The module is assessed by an extended piece of writing and a report. This module is ideal for students who want a career in scientific research and to develop a basis for postgraduate studies.
Outline Syllabus
Students will cover the following topics:

1. Anti-bacterial drug resistance: causes and solutions (Professor Nicola Williams)

2. Molecular pathogenesis and reverse vaccinology of digital dermatitis (Professor Nick Evans)

3. Molecular approaches to the life cycles of tick-borne intracellular bacterial pathogens (Professor Ben Makepeace)

4. Epidemiological approaches to infection control in complex disease settings (Dr Hannah Vineer, Dr Lian Thomas)

5. Comparative genomics and reverse vaccinology of African trypanosomiasis (Dr Andrew Jackson)

6. Genomic basis of drug resistance and vaccine development for fasciolosis (Professor Jane Hodgkinson, Dr Krystyna Cwiklinski)

7. Molecular and cellular biology of herpesvirus infection (Professor James Stewart)

8. Epidemiology and control of coronaviruses in domestic and companion animals (Professor Alan Radford, Dr Kannan Ganapathy)

9. Avian influenza in animal and human populations (TBD)

This syllabus is subject to alteration by suitable substitutions, in the event of personnel changes and dependent on staff availability.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The pedagogical strategy for the module is designed to deliver advanced biological knowledge but also authentic descriptions of the research process involved in translation, while fulfilling the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Each of the nine disease topics will be taught through three sessions.

1. A LECTURE providing the facts and concepts required to understand the prevailing scientific consensus, including any ‘refresher’ required of the basic biology introduced in previous years.

2. A SEMINAR describing relevant infection biology research at UoL, focusing on the techniques used to translate basic biology into novel diagnostic or therapeutic benefits. This ensures that teaching is research-connected.

3. a) A PRACTICAL (x3) providing practical experience of a relevant research method [i.e. i) bioinformatic approaches to genetic variation; ii) molecular biology techniques for identifying phenotypic variation; iii) taxonomic techniques for identifying pathogens] and opportunities to consider the need for safe working practices and research integrity (i.e. record-keeping); or
b) A TUTORIAL (x6) providing an opportunity for clarification and exploration of key concepts covered in lecture and seminar, development of confident spoken communication. Where possible, tutorials will introduce clinical research and practice at UoL related to the topic as part of the wider discussion. This third component ensures that active learning is a substantial part of the student experience.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is explicitly linked to the active learning sessions (I.e. practical/tutorial) within the module, ensuring that assessment is authentic. The strategy for assessment observes five priorities: (1) to rigorously examine student understanding of taught material; (2) to develop written communication skills in relation to the research process, (3) to promote scholarship, integration and synopsis, (4) to be robust to the possibility of fabrication and (5) to ensure attendance of practical and tutorial sessions.

Summative assessment will consist of two assignments:

1. A 1,500-word technical report based on one of three practical sessions (not advertised beforehand), to be completed to journal specifications provided. This will include an account of the experiment and research method, results and findings. Students will need to demonstrate that they have displayed research integrity. The discussion of the report will need to display a critical comparison with the literature relating to the specific research method concerned. Scientific report writing is an essential scientific skill required for both further study and by employers in STEM.

2. A 2,000-word review article/essay based on one of six tutorial sessions (not advertised beforehand), to be completed to journal specifications provided. This will include a graphical abstract, three further original figures to illustrate the subject matter, and explanatory boxes on key concepts. Students will need to demonstrate a thorough familiarity with the literature relating to the selected disease system. Critiquing scientific literature is an essential scientific skill required for both further study and by employers in STEM.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Scientific writing and communication is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task.


Formative assessment will consist of selected journal articles or data sets introduced in tutorials, accompanied by multiple choice questions on the science and methodology, for each of the nine disease topics. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Veterinary Infection Biology: Research and Translation 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS321

Online · Semester 1
 
In Programmes:Bioveterinary Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25

Blurb
Overview
The purpose of Veterinary Infection Biology is to provide students with detailed knowledge of infectious diseases in livestock and companion animals, as well the contemporary research techniques used at the University of Liverpool (UoL) to acquire such knowledge.

Our intention is for students to acquire
(1) accurate understanding of the prevailing scientific consensus on disease cause and control,
(2) understanding of how new knowledge is being exploited to improve outcomes in the disease setting, and
(3) a good appreciation for the research process, how problems are addressed and data interpreted.

The module will cover nine different infectious diseases including viral, bacterial and parasitological pathogens, building on basic biology of these organisms delivered in years 1 and 2. All of these diseases comprise active research programmes at the University, and teaching will be research-led, drawing on diverse methods (molecular, cellular, epidemiology, clinical). It is delivered through a combination of lectures, research seminars, small-group tutorials and practicals. The module is assessed by an extended piece of writing and a report.

The forms of assessment will encourage students to scrutinize the research process and actively prepare them for postgraduate studies by focusing on
(1) new research skills gained in practical sessions and
(2) scientific interpretation in tutorials.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to deliver an advanced biology of global veterinary infectious disease and to immerse students in the research process at UoL. Our intention is that the module will prepare students for postgraduate study and instil confidence in them to consider careers in research. The module covers nine topics spanning the spectrum of veterinary pathogens. The module fulfils the Liverpool Hallmarks; all topics are active research programmes at UoL, meaning that we can deliver authentic research-led teaching.

There are five objectives:

1. Deliver advanced knowledge from multiple research perspectives (i.e. molecular biology, genetics, epidemiology, ecology, clinical) to a level that approaches a professional standard.

2. Explicitly link basic biology to translational research at UoL, ensuring that all content is outcome-orientated and authentically research-led.

3. Explicitly link basic biology to clinical research and practice at UoL, ensuring that content is secured in its global veterinary context, (including one-health perspectives where appropriate), to produce a holistic understanding of disease cause and control that relates real-world complexities.

4. Describe the contemporary molecular, epidemiological and computational techniques used in veterinary infection biology research at UoL, providing practical experience of select methods to students, and demonstrate how diverse data are interpreted to create knowledge in the research process.

5. Cultivate students’ understanding and spoken communication skills in relation to select topics through regular active learning, and develop their critical analysis skills with regard to scientific consensus and research process through authentic assessment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Infectious disease is a key aspect of animal health and well-being, and so understanding infection is critical for people working with animals or veterinarians. This module explains the detailed biology of important animal infections and how this is being translated into novel disease therapies, drawing on the first-hand experience of veterinary scientists at the University of Liverpool. It is delivered through a combination of lectures, research seminars, small-group tutorials and practicals. The module is assessed by an extended piece of writing and a report. This module is ideal for students who want a career in scientific research and to develop a basis for postgraduate studies.
Outline Syllabus
Students will cover the following topics:

1. Anti-bacterial drug resistance: causes and solutions (Professor Nicola Williams)

2. Molecular pathogenesis and reverse vaccinology of digital dermatitis (Professor Nick Evans)

3. Molecular approaches to the life cycles of tick-borne intracellular bacterial pathogens (Professor Ben Makepeace)

4. Epidemiological approaches to infection control in complex disease settings (Dr Hannah Vineer, Dr Lian Thomas)

5. Comparative genomics and reverse vaccinology of African trypanosomiasis (Dr Andrew Jackson)

6. Genomic basis of drug resistance and vaccine development for fasciolosis (Professor Jane Hodgkinson, Dr Krystyna Cwiklinski)

7. Molecular and cellular biology of herpesvirus infection (Professor James Stewart)

8. Epidemiology and control of coronaviruses in domestic and companion animals (Professor Alan Radford, Dr Kannan Ganapathy)

9. Avian influenza in animal and human populations (TBD)

This syllabus is subject to alteration by suitable substitutions, in the event of personnel changes and dependent on staff availability.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The pedagogical strategy for the module is designed to deliver advanced biological knowledge but also authentic descriptions of the research process involved in translation, while fulfilling the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Each of the nine disease topics will be taught through three sessions.

1. A LECTURE providing the facts and concepts required to understand the prevailing scientific consensus, including any ‘refresher’ required of the basic biology introduced in previous years.

2. A SEMINAR describing relevant infection biology research at UoL, focusing on the techniques used to translate basic biology into novel diagnostic or therapeutic benefits. This ensures that teaching is research-connected.

3. a) A PRACTICAL (x3) providing practical experience of a relevant research method [i.e. i) bioinformatic approaches to genetic variation; ii) molecular biology techniques for identifying phenotypic variation; iii) taxonomic techniques for identifying pathogens] and opportunities to consider the need for safe working practices and research integrity (i.e. record-keeping); or
b) A TUTORIAL (x6) providing an opportunity for clarification and exploration of key concepts covered in lecture and seminar, development of confident spoken communication. Where possible, tutorials will introduce clinical research and practice at UoL related to the topic as part of the wider discussion. This third component ensures that active learning is a substantial part of the student experience.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is explicitly linked to the active learning sessions (I.e. practical/tutorial) within the module, ensuring that assessment is authentic. The strategy for assessment observes five priorities: (1) to rigorously examine student understanding of taught material; (2) to develop written communication skills in relation to the research process, (3) to promote scholarship, integration and synopsis, (4) to be robust to the possibility of fabrication and (5) to ensure attendance of practical and tutorial sessions.

Summative assessment will consist of two assignments:

1. A 1,500-word technical report based on one of three practical sessions (not advertised beforehand), to be completed to journal specifications provided. This will include an account of the experiment and research method, results and findings. Students will need to demonstrate that they have displayed research integrity. The discussion of the report will need to display a critical comparison with the literature relating to the specific research method concerned. Scientific report writing is an essential scientific skill required for both further study and by employers in STEM.

2. A 2,000-word review article/essay based on one of six tutorial sessions (not advertised beforehand), to be completed to journal specifications provided. This will include a graphical abstract, three further original figures to illustrate the subject matter, and explanatory boxes on key concepts. Students will need to demonstrate a thorough familiarity with the literature relating to the selected disease system. Critiquing scientific literature is an essential scientific skill required for both further study and by employers in STEM.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Scientific writing and communication is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task.


Formative assessment will consist of selected journal articles or data sets introduced in tutorials, accompanied by multiple choice questions on the science and methodology, for each of the nine disease topics. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome

 LO5 critically evaluate others’ findings, synthesize data in the context of existing knowledge and produce a valid consensus, displaying digital fluency in their written assessments.

The module fulfils the Liverpool Hallmarks; all topics are active research programmes at UoL, meaning that we can deliver authentic research-led teaching.

There are five objectives:

1. Deliver advanced knowledge from multiple research perspectives (i.e. molecular biology, genetics, epidemiology, ecology, clinical) to a level that approaches a professional standard.

2. Explicitly link basic biology to translational research at UoL, ensuring that all content is outcome-orientated and authentically research-led.

3. Explicitly link basic biology to clinical research and practice at UoL, ensuring that content is secured in its global veterinary context, (including one-health perspectives where appropriate), to produce a holistic understanding of disease cause and control that relates real-world complexities.

4. Describe the contemporary molecular, epidemiological and computational techniques used in veterinary infection biology research at UoL, providing practical experience of select methods to students, and demonstrate how diverse data are interpreted to create knowledge in the research process.

5. Cultivate students’ understanding and spoken communication skills in relation to select topics through regular active learning, and develop their critical analysis skills with regard to scientific consensus and research process through authentic assessment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Infectious disease is a key aspect of animal health and well-being, and so understanding infection is critical for people working with animals or veterinarians. This module explains the detailed biology of important animal infections and how this is being translated into novel disease therapies, drawing on the first-hand experience of veterinary scientists at the University of Liverpool. It is delivered through a combination of lectures, research seminars, small-group tutorials and practicals. The module is assessed by an extended piece of writing and a report. This module is ideal for students who want a career in scientific research and to develop a basis for postgraduate studies.
Outline Syllabus
Students will cover the following topics:

1. Anti-bacterial drug resistance: causes and solutions (Professor Nicola Williams)

2. Molecular pathogenesis and reverse vaccinology of digital dermatitis (Professor Nick Evans)

3. Molecular approaches to the life cycles of tick-borne intracellular bacterial pathogens (Professor Ben Makepeace)

4. Epidemiological approaches to infection control in complex disease settings (Dr Hannah Vineer, Dr Lian Thomas)

5. Comparative genomics and reverse vaccinology of African trypanosomiasis (Dr Andrew Jackson)

6. Genomic basis of drug resistance and vaccine development for fasciolosis (Professor Jane Hodgkinson, Dr Krystyna Cwiklinski)

7. Molecular and cellular biology of herpesvirus infection (Professor James Stewart)

8. Epidemiology and control of coronaviruses in domestic and companion animals (Professor Alan Radford, Dr Kannan Ganapathy)

9. Avian influenza in animal and human populations (TBD)

This syllabus is subject to alteration by suitable substitutions, in the event of personnel changes and dependent on staff availability.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The pedagogical strategy for the module is designed to deliver advanced biological knowledge but also authentic descriptions of the research process involved in translation, while fulfilling the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Each of the nine disease topics will be taught through three sessions.

1. A LECTURE providing the facts and concepts required to understand the prevailing scientific consensus, including any ‘refresher’ required of the basic biology introduced in previous years.

2. A SEMINAR describing relevant infection biology research at UoL, focusing on the techniques used to translate basic biology into novel diagnostic or therapeutic benefits. This ensures that teaching is research-connected.

3. a) A PRACTICAL (x3) providing practical experience of a relevant research method [i.e. i) bioinformatic approaches to genetic variation; ii) molecular biology techniques for identifying phenotypic variation; iii) taxonomic techniques for identifying pathogens] and opportunities to consider the need for safe working practices and research integrity (i.e. record-keeping); or
b) A TUTORIAL (x6) providing an opportunity for clarification and exploration of key concepts covered in lecture and seminar, development of confident spoken communication. Where possible, tutorials will introduce clinical research and practice at UoL related to the topic as part of the wider discussion. This third component ensures that active learning is a substantial part of the student experience.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is explicitly linked to the active learning sessions (I.e. practical/tutorial) within the module, ensuring that assessment is authentic. The strategy for assessment observes five priorities: (1) to rigorously examine student understanding of taught material; (2) to develop written communication skills in relation to the research process, (3) to promote scholarship, integration and synopsis, (4) to be robust to the possibility of fabrication and (5) to ensure attendance of practical and tutorial sessions.

Summative assessment will consist of two assignments:

1. A 1,500-word technical report based on one of three practical sessions (not advertised beforehand), to be completed to journal specifications provided. This will include an account of the experiment and research method, results and findings. Students will need to demonstrate that they have displayed research integrity. The discussion of the report will need to display a critical comparison with the literature relating to the specific research method concerned. Scientific report writing is an essential scientific skill required for both further study and by employers in STEM.

2. A 2,000-word review article/essay based on one of six tutorial sessions (not advertised beforehand), to be completed to journal specifications provided. This will include a graphical abstract, three further original figures to illustrate the subject matter, and explanatory boxes on key concepts. Students will need to demonstrate a thorough familiarity with the literature relating to the selected disease system. Critiquing scientific literature is an essential scientific skill required for both further study and by employers in STEM.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Scientific writing and communication is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task.


Formative assessment will consist of selected journal articles or data sets introduced in tutorials, accompanied by multiple choice questions on the science and methodology, for each of the nine disease topics. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
The purpose of Veterinary Infection Biology is to provide students with detailed knowledge of infectious diseases in livestock and companion animals, as well the contemporary research techniques used at the University of Liverpool (UoL) to acquire such knowledge.

Our intention is for students to acquire
(1) accurate understanding of the prevailing scientific consensus on disease cause and control,
(2) understanding of how new knowledge is being exploited to improve outcomes in the disease setting, and
(3) a good appreciation for the research process, how problems are addressed and data interpreted.

The module will cover nine different infectious diseases including viral, bacterial and parasitological pathogens, building on basic biology of these organisms delivered in years 1 and 2. All of these diseases comprise active research programmes at the University, and teaching will be research-led, drawing on diverse methods (molecular, cellular, epidemiology, clinical). It is delivered through a combination of lectures, research seminars, small-group tutorials and practicals. The module is assessed by an extended piece of writing and a report.

The forms of assessment will encourage students to scrutinize the research process and actively prepare them for postgraduate studies by focusing on
(1) new research skills gained in practical sessions and
(2) scientific interpretation in tutorials.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to deliver an advanced biology of global veterinary infectious disease and to immerse students in the research process at UoL. Our intention is that the module will prepare students for postgraduate study and instil confidence in them to consider careers in research. The module covers nine topics spanning the spectrum of veterinary pathogens. The module fulfils the Liverpool Hallmarks; all topics are active research programmes at UoL, meaning that we can deliver authentic research-led teaching.

There are five objectives:

1. Deliver advanced knowledge from multiple research perspectives (i.e. molecular biology, genetics, epidemiology, ecology, clinical) to a level that approaches a professional standard.

2. Explicitly link basic biology to translational research at UoL, ensuring that all content is outcome-orientated and authentically research-led.

3. Explicitly link basic biology to clinical research and practice at UoL, ensuring that content is secured in its global veterinary context, (including one-health perspectives where appropriate), to produce a holistic understanding of disease cause and control that relates real-world complexities.

4. Describe the contemporary molecular, epidemiological and computational techniques used in veterinary infection biology research at UoL, providing practical experience of select methods to students, and demonstrate how diverse data are interpreted to create knowledge in the research process.

5. Cultivate students’ understanding and spoken communication skills in relation to select topics through regular active learning, and develop their critical analysis skills with regard to scientific consensus and research process through authentic assessment.
